tit.cmt: 姫→ハイフン+hime としました。

sen.j: 抓津姫神（つまつひめ）は、日本神話に登場する神。
sen.e: Tsumatsuhime is a god who appeared in Japanese Mythology.
Tsumatsuhime is a goddess in Japanese mythology.
Tsumatsu-hime is a goddess in Japanese mythology.
sen.cmt: 姫→ハイフン+hime としました。

sen.j: 都麻都比賣命・爪津姫神・枛津姫神などと表記する。
sen.e: Tsumatsuhime is described as 都麻都比賣命, 爪津姫神, or 津姫神.
Her name is written in Japanese as 都麻都比賣命, 爪津姫神, or 津姫神.
Her name is written in Japanese as 都麻都比賣命, 爪津姫神, or 津姫神.

sen.j: スサノオの娘で、兄に五十猛神、姉に大屋都比賣神がいる。
sen.e: Tsumatsuhime is a daughter of Susano, and has an elder brother Isotakerunokami and a younger sister Oyatsuhime.
Tsumatsuhime is a daughter of Susanoo (the god of storms and the sea), and has an elder brother, Isotakerunokami, and a younger sister, Oyatsuhime.
sen.cmt: Spelling of SusanooAdded explanation of who Susanoo wasPunctuation
sen.e: Tsumatsu-hime is a daughter of Susanoo (the god of storms and the sea), and has an elder brother, Isotakeru no Kami, and a younger sister, Oyatsu-hime.
sen.cmt: 姫→ハイフン+hime としました。スペースを追加して、Isotakeru no Kami としました。

sen.j: 「ツマ」は建物を築くために製材した材木を意味する。
sen.e: tsuma' means lumber used to construct building.
Tsuma' means lumber used to construct buildings.
The word 'Tsuma' means lumber used to construct buildings.
sen.cmt: 一部文頭に翻訳を追加しました。

sen.j: 抓津姫神は、兄の五十猛神や姉の大屋津姫神と共に木の文化を司るとされ、木造建築などの女神として崇拝されている。
sen.e: It is said that Tsumatsuhime governs wood culture together with an elder brother Isotakerunokami and a younger sister Oyatsuhime, and is worshipped as the female god of wooden architecture.
It is said that Tsumatsuhime, together with her brother, Isotakerunokami, and sister, Oyatsuhime, governs wood culture and is worshipped as the goddess of wooden buildings.
It is said that Tsumatsu-hime, together with her brother, Isotakeru no Kami, and sister, Oyatsu-hime, governs wood culture and is worshipped as the goddess of wooden buildings.
sen.cmt: 姫→ハイフン+hime としました。

sen.j: 『日本書紀』 卷第一 第八段の第五の一書は以下のような記述となっている。
sen.e: According to Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) Volume 1, Part 8, 5, 1 (卷第一 第八段の第五の一書)
sen.cmt: 卷第一 第八段の第五の一書 定訳不明
sen.e: According to the fifth addendum to chapter eight of the first volume of the "Nihonshoki,"
The fifth addendum to chapter eight in the first volume of the "Nihonshoki" mentions Tsumatsu-hime in the following passage.
sen.cmt: 原文（和文）を一部変更し、英文もそれに応じて一部変更しました。

sen.j: 一書曰 素戔嗚尊曰 韓郷之嶋 是有金銀 若使吾兒所御之國 不有浮寶者 未是佳也 乃拔鬚髯散之 即成杉 又拔散胸毛 是成檜 尻毛是成柀 眉毛是成櫲樟 已而定其當用 乃稱之曰 杉及櫲樟 此兩樹者 可以爲浮寶 檜可以爲瑞宮之材 柀可以爲顯見蒼生奥津棄戸將臥之具 夫須噉八十木種 皆能播生 于時 素戔嗚尊之子 號曰五十猛命 妹大屋津姫命 次枛津姫命 凡此三神 亦能分布木種 即奉渡於紀伊國也 然後 素戔嗚尊 居熊成峯 而遂入於根國者矣棄戸 此云須多杯 柀 此云磨紀
sen.e: 一書曰 素戔嗚尊曰 韓郷之嶋 是有金銀 若使吾兒所御之國 不有浮寶者 未是佳也 乃拔鬚髯散之 即成杉 又拔散胸毛 是成檜 尻毛是成柀 眉毛是成櫲樟 已而定其當用 乃稱之曰 杉及櫲樟 此兩樹者 可以爲浮寶 檜可以爲瑞宮之材 柀可以爲顯見蒼生奥津棄戸將臥之具 夫須噉八十木種 皆能播生 于時 素戔嗚尊之子 號曰五十猛命 妹大屋津姫命 次枛津姫命 凡此三神 亦能分布木種 即奉渡於紀伊國也 然後 素戔嗚尊 居熊成峯 而遂入於根國者矣棄戸 此云須多杯 柀 此云磨紀

一書曰 素戔嗚尊曰 韓郷之嶋 是有金銀 若使吾兒所御之國 不有浮寶者 未是佳也 乃拔鬚髯散之 即成杉 又拔散胸毛 是成檜 尻毛是成柀 眉毛是成櫲樟 已而定其當用 乃稱之曰 杉及櫲樟 此兩樹者 可以爲浮寶 檜可以爲瑞宮之材 柀可以爲顯見蒼生奥津棄戸將臥之具 夫須噉八十木種 皆能播生 于時 素戔嗚尊之子 號曰五十猛命 妹大屋津姫命 次枛津姫命 凡此三神 亦能分布木種 即奉渡於紀伊國也 然後 素戔嗚尊 居熊成峯 而遂入於根國者矣棄戸 此云須多杯 柀 此云磨紀

Susanoo said, "There is gold and silver in the islands of Karakuni (considered to be a part of present-day Korea), so it is not good that the country controlled by my children doesn't have any ships." Then, he pulled out some hairs of his beard and scattered them, and then, they turned into cedars. He continued pulling out some hairs from parts of his body. The hairs he picked from his chest turned into hinoki (Japanese cypresses), the hairs he picked from his buttocks turned into maki (Japanese yew pines), and his plucked eyebrows turned into camphor trees. After that, he decided on the use of each tree and suggested, "Cedars and camphor trees should be used for making ships, Japanese cypresses should be used for constructing palaces, Japanese yew pines should be used for coffins when the body is buried. Everyone should join together to sow seeds of many trees used for these various purposes and grow many more trees." Around this time, he had a son, Isotakeru, and two daughters, Oyatsu-hime and Tsumatsu-hime. These three gods contributed to sowing seeds and growing trees all across the nation, and then they moved to Kii Province (the southern part of present-day Mie and Wakayama Prefectures) where they were enshrined. After that, Susanoo finally entered Ne-no-kuni (underworld) via Kumanarinotake.
sen.cmt: 「大屋都比賣神」 のファイルの翻訳を流用しました。

sen.j: 上記によれば、素戔嗚尊の鬚髯からスギ、胸毛からヒノキ、眉毛からクスノキなどの木々が生じた。
sen.e: Japanese cedar arose from beard of Susanoo-no-mikoto, Japanese cypress from his chest hair, and camphor tree from his eyebrow.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Japanese cedars grew from Susanoo-no-mikoto's beard, Japanese cypresses from his chest hair, and camphor trees from his eyebrows.
According to the above passage, Japanese cedars grew from Susanoo no Mikoto's beard, Japanese cypresses from his chest hair, and camphor trees from his eyebrows.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを削除し、Susanoo no Mikoto としました。前文からのつながりを考慮し、一部原文（和文）と英文の冒頭を変更しました。

sen.j: そして、素戔嗚尊から各々の用途を教えられた3人の子は日本全国の山々にこれらの種を蒔いて回ったという。
sen.e: Then, three children of Susanoo-no-mikoto learned how to use each tree from him and visited every mountains in the country to plant these seeds.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, the three children of Susanoo-no-mikoto learned how to use each tree from him and visited every mountain in the country to plant these seeds.
Then, the three children of Susanoo no Mikoto learned how to use each tree from him and visited every mountain in the country to plant these seeds.
sen.cmt: ハイフンを削除し、Susanoo no Mikoto としました。

sen.j: 日本紀講筵の際提出された偽書とされる『先代旧事本紀』巻第四 地祇本紀では、以下のような記述となっている。
sen.e: Sendai Kujihongi (Ancient Japanese History) which is regarded as an apocryphal book submitted at Nihongi Koen (a court function of lecture on the "Chronicles of Japan" in Heian period) says:
The "Chigi hongi" (Original Record of Earthly Deities), which is chapter four of the "Sendai Kujihongi", a text that appeared in the Heian period but whose authenticity is disputed, says:
The "Chigi hongi" (Original Record of Earthly Deities), which is chapter four of the "Sendai Kujihongi," a text that appeared in the Heian period but whose authenticity is disputed, says as follows:
sen.cmt: カンマの位置をクォーテーションマークの中に移動しました。

sen.j: 一説曰 素戔烏尊之子 號曰 五十猛命 妹 大屋姫命 次 抓津姫命 凡三神 亦能分布八十木種 則奉渡於紀伊國 及此國所祭之神是也
sen.e: 一説曰 素戔烏尊之子 號曰 五十猛命 妹 大屋姫命 次 抓津姫命 凡三神 亦能分布八十木種 則奉渡於紀伊國 及此國所祭之神是也
一説曰 素戔烏尊之子 號曰 五十猛命 妹 大屋姫命 次 抓津姫命 凡三神 亦能分布八十木種 則奉渡於紀伊國 及此國所祭之神是也

Susanoo had a son, Isotakeru and two daughters, Oyatsu-hime and Tsumatsu-hime. These three gods contributed to sowing seeds and growing trees all across the nation, and then they moved to Kii Province where they were enshrined.
sen.cmt: 「大屋都比賣神」 のファイルの翻訳を流用しました。

sen.j: 素戔烏尊 此尊與天照太神共誓約（中略）次 五十猛命 亦云 大屋彦神 次 大屋姫神 次 抓津姫神 已上三柱 並坐 紀伊國 則紀伊國造齋祠神也
sen.e: 素戔烏尊 此尊與天照太神共誓約(中略)次 五十猛命 亦云 大屋彦神 次 大屋姫神 次 抓津姫神 已上三柱 並坐 紀伊國 則紀伊國造齋祠神也
素戔烏尊 此尊與天照太神共誓約(中略)次 五十猛命 亦云 大屋彦神 次 大屋姫神 次 抓津姫神 已上三柱 並坐 紀伊國 則紀伊國造齋祠神也

Susanoo and Amaterasu made a pledge to prove their sincerity (...) His next child was a son named Isotakeru, also called Oyahiko no Kami. After Isotakeru, he had two daughters, Oyatsu-hime and Tsumatsu-hime. These three gods were enshrined in Kii Province, which means the Kinokuni no Miyatsuko (governor or ruler of Kii Province) worshiped them devoutly as deities.
sen.cmt: 「大屋都比賣神」 のファイルの翻訳を流用しました。
